comment_text.mn62:1.1: Compared to MN 61, now the Buddha is assigning advanced practices to Rāhula, recommending a diverse range of different meditations. | The unusual structure raises questions as to its historicity, which I will discuss in my final note, having noted relevant details along the way.
comment_text.mn62:2.2: According to the commentary, Rāhula was now eighteen years old, situating this sutta several years after MN 61.
comment_text.mn62:3.3: The commentary says that the Buddha admonished him because he was admiring his father’s beauty, thinking that he looked similar. See MN 61:8.2, which similarly implies that vanity was a weakness of Rāhula.
comment_text.mn62:4.1: He decides to meditate rather than eat for that day.
comment_text.mn62:5.1: Rāhula would have still been a novice (sāmaṇera) as he was not yet twenty. It was Sāriputta who ordained him (Kd 1:54.2.7).
comment_text.mn62:7.1: The Pali text has a striking narrative form. The Buddha encourages Rāhula to contemplate form; then Sāriputta urges him in breath meditation; but when Rāhula asks the Buddha about that, the Buddha ignores him (until much later in the sutta) and instead expands on his instructions on form. The Chinese parallel (EA 17.1 at T ii 581c–582c) paints quite a different picture. Sāriputta does not appear at all, and it is the Buddha who instructs Rāhula when he is meditating, teaching him not just mindfulness of breathing but also the meditations on the ugliness of the body and the divine abidings. Then, when Rāhula approaches him later to ask further about mindfulness of breathing, the Buddha teaches him this right away, omitting entirely the long section on the elements. Both suttas agree on teaching Rāhula a range of meditations, but the Pali implies that he needed to mature his mind with a range of other meditations before attempting mindfulness of breathing, a situation of which Sāriputta was not aware.
comment_text.mn62:8.1: This largely follows MN 140:14.4 and MN 28:4.1, the latter of which was taught by Sāriputta. There the expanded teaching is clearly situated within the contemplation of form, whereas here it is somewhat abrupt.
comment_text.mn62:12.5: The MS edition has an extended passage here that appears to be imported from the Abhidhamma (eg, Vb 3:10.5). It would translate as: “space, spacious, void, voidness, opening, openness, untouched, and appropriated by flesh and blood.”
comment_text.mn62:13.3: This simile and those that follow on water, fire, and wind are found at AN 9.11:4.1, where they are also spoken by Sāriputta.
comment_text.mn62:17.3: This phrase is unique in the early texts. It is quoted by name in Mil 7.4.6:5.4.
comment_text.mn62:25.2: For notes on this practice, see MN 118:17.2.
comment_text.mn62:30.4: The Chinese parallel presents a fuller picture of Rāhula’s progress at this point, saying he went away, developed jhānas, and became an arahant, before returning to announce this to the Buddha, who praised him as the foremost of those desiring training. In the Pali, Rāhula’s awakening occurs differently in MN 147, while he is praised for desiring training at AN 1.209:1.1. | It is not easy to assess the historical authenticity of this sutta. The Chinese version presents a more coherent narrative that may indicate less corruption. Yet it expands the ending, making the sutta a comprehensive account of Rāhula’s progress. The collection from which it stems, the Ekottarikāgama, is the latest and least orthodox of extant Āgama collections, and it could be that it has streamlined a knotty narrative. The Pali, with its abrupt narrative transition and its implication that Sāriputta got his meditation instructions wrong, has more of the randomness of natural dialogue. Yet the fact that the portions extra to the Chinese include not only the person of Sāriputta, but also teachings associated with Sāriputta, is hard to explain as a loss of text. Perhaps both texts have been expanded from a simpler original where the Buddha teaches meditation to his son.

root_text.mn62:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn62:2.1: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn62:2.2: Āyasmāpi kho rāhulo pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya bhagavantaṁ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
root_text.mn62:3.1: Atha kho bhagavā apaloketvā āyasmantaṁ rāhulaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn62:3.2: “yaṁ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṁ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā—sabbaṁ rūpaṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabban”ti.
root_text.mn62:3.3: “Rūpameva nu kho, bhagavā, rūpameva nu kho, sugatā”ti?
root_text.mn62:3.4: “Rūpampi, rāhula, vedanāpi, rāhula, saññāpi, rāhula, saṅkhārāpi, rāhula, viññāṇampi, rāhulā”ti.
root_text.mn62:4.1: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo “ko najja bhagavatā sammukhā ovādena ovadito gāmaṁ piṇḍāya pavisissatī”ti tato paṭinivattitvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle nisīdi pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn62:5.1: Addasā kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṁ rāhulaṁ aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle nisinnaṁ pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn62:5.4: Ānāpānassati, rāhula, bhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā”ti.
root_text.mn62:6.1: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn62:7.1: “kathaṁ bhāvitā nu kho, bhante, ānāpānassati, kathaṁ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā”ti?
root_text.mn62:8.1: “Yaṁ kiñci, rāhula, ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ kakkhaḷaṁ kharigataṁ upādinnaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn62:8.2: kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ, yaṁ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ kakkhaḷaṁ kharigataṁ upādinnaṁ—
root_text.mn62:8.4: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu yā ca bāhirā pathavīdhātu, pathavīdhāturevesā.
root_text.mn62:8.5: Taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn62:8.6: Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindati, pathavīdhātuyā cittaṁ virājeti.
root_text.mn62:9.4: Yaṁ ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ āpo āpogataṁ upādinnaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn62:9.5: pittaṁ semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttaṁ, yaṁ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ āpo āpogataṁ upādinnaṁ—
root_text.mn62:9.7: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā āpodhātu yā ca bāhirā āpodhātu āpodhāturevesā.
root_text.mn62:9.8: Taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn62:9.9: Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā āpodhātuyā nibbindati, āpodhātuyā cittaṁ virājeti.
root_text.mn62:10.4: Yaṁ ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ tejo tejogataṁ upādinnaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn62:10.5: yena ca santappati yena ca jīrīyati yena ca pariḍayhati yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṁ sammā pariṇāmaṁ gacchati, yaṁ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ tejo tejogataṁ upādinnaṁ—
root_text.mn62:10.7: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā tejodhātu yā ca bāhirā tejodhātu tejodhāturevesā.
root_text.mn62:10.8: Taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn62:10.9: Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā tejodhātuyā nibbindati, tejodhātuyā cittaṁ virājeti.
root_text.mn62:11.4: Yaṁ ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ vāyo vāyogataṁ upādinnaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn62:11.5: uddhaṅgamā vātā, adhogamā vātā, kucchisayā vātā, koṭṭhāsayā vātā, aṅgamaṅgānusārino vātā, assāso passāso iti, yaṁ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ vāyo vāyogataṁ upādinnaṁ—
root_text.mn62:11.7: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā vāyodhātu yā ca bāhirā vāyodhātu vāyodhāturevesā.
root_text.mn62:11.8: Taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn62:11.9: Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā vāyodhātuyā nibbindati, vāyodhātuyā cittaṁ virājeti.
root_text.mn62:12.4: Yaṁ ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ ākāsaṁ ākāsagataṁ upādinnaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn62:12.5: kaṇṇacchiddaṁ nāsacchiddaṁ mukhadvāraṁ, yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṁ ajjhoharati, yattha ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṁ santiṭṭhati, yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṁ adhobhāgaṁ nikkhamati, yaṁ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ ākāsaṁ ākāsagataṁ, aghaṁ aghagataṁ, vivaraṁ vivaragataṁ, asamphuṭṭhaṁ, maṁsalohitehi upādinnaṁ—
root_text.mn62:12.7: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā ākāsadhātu yā ca bāhirā ākāsadhātu ākāsadhāturevesā.
root_text.mn62:12.8: Taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn62:12.9: Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā ākāsadhātuyā cittaṁ nibbindati, ākāsadhātuyā cittaṁ virājeti.
root_text.mn62:13.2: Pathavīsamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:13.3: Seyyathāpi, rāhula, pathaviyā sucimpi nikkhipanti, asucimpi nikkhipanti, gūthagatampi nikkhipanti, muttagatampi nikkhipanti, kheḷagatampi nikkhipanti, pubbagatampi nikkhipanti, lohitagatampi nikkhipanti, na ca tena pathavī aṭṭīyati vā harāyati vā jigucchati vā;
root_text.mn62:13.4: evameva kho tvaṁ, rāhula, pathavīsamaṁ bhāvanaṁ bhāvehi.
root_text.mn62:13.5: Pathavīsamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:14.2: Āposamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:14.3: Seyyathāpi, rāhula, āpasmiṁ sucimpi dhovanti, asucimpi dhovanti, gūthagatampi dhovanti, muttagatampi dhovanti, kheḷagatampi dhovanti, pubbagatampi dhovanti, lohitagatampi dhovanti, na ca tena āpo aṭṭīyati vā harāyati vā jigucchati vā;
root_text.mn62:14.4: evameva kho tvaṁ, rāhula, āposamaṁ bhāvanaṁ bhāvehi.
root_text.mn62:14.5: Āposamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:15.2: Tejosamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:15.3: Seyyathāpi, rāhula, tejo sucimpi dahati, asucimpi dahati, gūthagatampi dahati, muttagatampi dahati, kheḷagatampi dahati, pubbagatampi dahati, lohitagatampi dahati, na ca tena tejo aṭṭīyati vā harāyati vā jigucchati vā;
root_text.mn62:15.4: evameva kho tvaṁ, rāhula, tejosamaṁ bhāvanaṁ bhāvehi.
root_text.mn62:15.5: Tejosamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:16.2: Vāyosamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:16.3: Seyyathāpi, rāhula, vāyo sucimpi upavāyati, asucimpi upavāyati, gūthagatampi upavāyati, muttagatampi upavāyati, kheḷagatampi upavāyati, pubbagatampi upavāyati, lohitagatampi upavāyati, na ca tena vāyo aṭṭīyati vā harāyati vā jigucchati vā;
root_text.mn62:16.4: evameva kho tvaṁ, rāhula, vāyosamaṁ bhāvanaṁ bhāvehi.
root_text.mn62:16.5: Vāyosamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:17.2: Ākāsasamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:17.3: Seyyathāpi, rāhula, ākāso na katthaci patiṭṭhito;
root_text.mn62:17.4: evameva kho tvaṁ, rāhula, ākāsasamaṁ bhāvanaṁ bhāvehi.
root_text.mn62:17.5: Ākāsasamañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato uppannā manāpāmanāpā phassā cittaṁ na pariyādāya ṭhassanti.
root_text.mn62:18.2: Mettañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato yo byāpādo so pahīyissati.
root_text.mn62:19.2: Karuṇañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato yā vihesā sā pahīyissati.
root_text.mn62:20.2: Muditañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato yā arati sā pahīyissati.
root_text.mn62:21.2: Upekkhañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato yo paṭigho so pahīyissati.
root_text.mn62:22.2: Asubhañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato yo rāgo so pahīyissati.
root_text.mn62:23.2: Aniccasaññañhi te, rāhula, bhāvanaṁ bhāvayato yo asmimāno so pahīyissati.
root_text.mn62:24.2: Ānāpānassati hi te, rāhula, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā.
root_text.mn62:24.3: Kathaṁ bhāvitā ca, rāhula, ānāpānassati, kathaṁ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā?
root_text.mn62:25.1: Idha, rāhula, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn62:26.1: Dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
root_text.mn62:26.2: rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn62:26.4: ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati; ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
root_text.mn62:27.4: ‘passambhayaṁ cittasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati; ‘passambhayaṁ cittasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
root_text.mn62:28.2: ‘abhippamodayaṁ cittaṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati; ‘abhippamodayaṁ cittaṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
root_text.mn62:28.3: ‘samādahaṁ cittaṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati; ‘samādahaṁ cittaṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
root_text.mn62:28.4: ‘vimocayaṁ cittaṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati; ‘vimocayaṁ cittaṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
root_text.mn62:30.1: Evaṁ bhāvitā kho, rāhula, ānāpānassati, evaṁ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā.
root_text.mn62:30.2: Evaṁ bhāvitāya, rāhula, ānāpānassatiyā, evaṁ bahulīkatāya yepi te carimakā assāsā tepi viditāva nirujjhanti no aviditā”ti.
root_text.mn62:30.4: Attamano āyasmā rāhulo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn62:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn62:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn62:2.2: And Venerable Rāhula also robed up and followed behind the Buddha.
translation_text.mn62:3.1: Then the Buddha looked back at Rāhula and said,
translation_text.mn62:3.2: “Rāhula, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’”
translation_text.mn62:3.3: “Only form, Blessed One? Only form, Holy One?”
translation_text.mn62:3.4: “Form, Rāhula, as well as feeling and perception and choices and consciousness.”
translation_text.mn62:4.1: Then Rāhula thought, “Who would go to the village for alms today after being advised directly by the Buddha?” Turning back, he sat down cross-legged at the root of a certain tree, setting his body straight, and establishing mindfulness in his presence.
translation_text.mn62:5.1: Venerable Sāriputta saw him sitting there,
translation_text.mn62:5.4: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.”
translation_text.mn62:6.1: Then in the late afternoon, Rāhula came out of retreat, went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
translation_text.mn62:7.1: “Sir, how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?”
translation_text.mn62:8.1: “Rāhula, the interior earth element is anything internal, personal, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn62:8.2: head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces; or anything else internal, personal, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn62:8.3: This is called the interior earth element.
translation_text.mn62:8.4: The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.
translation_text.mn62:8.5: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn62:8.6: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.
translation_text.mn62:9.1: And what is the water element?
translation_text.mn62:9.2: The water element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn62:9.3: And what is the interior water element?
translation_text.mn62:9.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s water, watery, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn62:9.5: bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine; or anything else internal, personal, that’s water, watery, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn62:9.6: This is called the interior water element.
translation_text.mn62:9.7: The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element.
translation_text.mn62:9.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn62:9.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.
translation_text.mn62:10.1: And what is the fire element?
translation_text.mn62:10.2: The fire element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn62:10.3: And what is the interior fire element?
translation_text.mn62:10.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn62:10.5: that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink; or anything else internal, personal, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn62:10.6: This is called the interior fire element.
translation_text.mn62:10.7: The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element.
translation_text.mn62:10.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn62:10.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.
translation_text.mn62:11.1: And what is the air element?
translation_text.mn62:11.2: The air element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn62:11.3: And what is the interior air element?
translation_text.mn62:11.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s air, airy, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn62:11.5: winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths; or anything else internal, personal, that’s air, airy, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn62:11.6: This is called the interior air element.
translation_text.mn62:11.7: The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element.
translation_text.mn62:11.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn62:11.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.
translation_text.mn62:12.1: And what is the space element?
translation_text.mn62:12.2: The space element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn62:12.3: And what is the interior space element?
translation_text.mn62:12.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s space, spacious, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn62:12.5: the ear canals, nostrils, and mouth; and the space for swallowing what is eaten and drunk, the space where it stays, and the space for excreting it from the nether regions; or anything else internal, personal, that’s space, spacious, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn62:12.6: This is called the interior space element.
translation_text.mn62:12.7: The interior space element and the exterior space element are just the space element.
translation_text.mn62:12.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn62:12.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the space element, detaching the mind from the space element.
translation_text.mn62:13.2: For when you meditate like the earth, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:13.3: Suppose they were to toss both clean and unclean things on the earth, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The earth isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this.
translation_text.mn62:13.4: In the same way, meditate like the earth.
translation_text.mn62:13.5: For when you meditate like the earth, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:14.2: For when you meditate like water, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:14.3: Suppose they were to wash both clean and unclean things in the water, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The water isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this.
translation_text.mn62:14.4: In the same way, meditate like water.
translation_text.mn62:14.5: For when you meditate like water, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:15.2: For when you meditate like fire, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:15.3: Suppose a fire were to burn both clean and unclean things, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The fire isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this.
translation_text.mn62:15.4: In the same way, meditate like fire.
translation_text.mn62:15.5: For when you meditate like fire, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:16.2: For when you meditate like wind, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:16.3: Suppose the wind were to blow on both clean and unclean things, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The wind isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this.
translation_text.mn62:16.4: In the same way, meditate like the wind.
translation_text.mn62:16.5: For when you meditate like wind, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:17.2: For when you meditate like space, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:17.3: Just as space is not established anywhere,
translation_text.mn62:17.4: in the same way, meditate like space.
translation_text.mn62:17.5: For when you meditate like space, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
translation_text.mn62:18.2: For when you meditate on love any ill will will be given up.
translation_text.mn62:19.2: For when you meditate on compassion any cruelty will be given up.
translation_text.mn62:20.2: For when you meditate on rejoicing any discontent will be given up.
translation_text.mn62:21.2: For when you meditate on equanimity any repulsion will be given up.
translation_text.mn62:22.2: For when you meditate on ugliness any lust will be given up.
translation_text.mn62:23.2: For when you meditate on impermanence any conceit ‘I am’ will be given up.
translation_text.mn62:24.2: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.mn62:24.3: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
translation_text.mn62:25.1: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn62:25.2: Just mindful, they breath in. Mindful, they breath out.
translation_text.mn62:26.1: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
translation_text.mn62:26.2: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
translation_text.mn62:26.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
translation_text.mn62:26.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
translation_text.mn62:27.1: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’
translation_text.mn62:27.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’
translation_text.mn62:27.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mental process.’
translation_text.mn62:27.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental process.’
translation_text.mn62:28.1: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’
translation_text.mn62:28.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’
translation_text.mn62:28.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’
translation_text.mn62:28.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’
translation_text.mn62:29.1: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’
translation_text.mn62:29.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’
translation_text.mn62:29.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’
translation_text.mn62:29.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
translation_text.mn62:30.1: Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.mn62:30.2: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated in this way, even as the final breaths cease they are known, not unknown.”
translation_text.mn62:30.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn62:30.4: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula approved what the Buddha said.
